{"abstract": "Exxon Mobil said output from its $17 billion Sakhalin Island development in the Pacific off Russia jumped 40 percent in the last month. Oil and natural gas production from the Sakhalin-1 development has risen to the equivalent of more than 200,000 barrels of crude a day, according to Stuart McGill, senior vice president. Exxon, which operates and owns a 30 percent stake in the project, expects output eventually to reach the equivalent of 317,000 barrels a day. Production at Sakhalin-1 was about 160,000 barrels a day in early December, a Bear Stearns analyst, Nicole Decker, said in a Dec. 13 note to clients after an analysts\u2019 lunch with Exxon\u2019s chief executive, Rex W. Tillerson. Exxon began producing crude from the Chayvo field off Sakhalin Island\u2019s ice-choked coastline in October 2005. Exxon\u2019s partners in Sakhalin-1 are a Japanese group known as Sodeco, the Oil and Natural Gas Corporation of India and the state-run Russian oil company Rosneft.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2007/01/18/business/worldbusiness/18fobriefs-SAKHALINPROD_BRF.html", "snippet": "Exxon Mobil said output from its $17 billion Sakhalin Island development in the Pacific off Russia jumped 40 percent in the last month. {"abstract": "Exxon Mobil said it would build a second chemicals factory in Singapore to meet rising demand in Asia.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2007/09/06/business/worldbusiness/06fobriefs-NEWPLANTFORE_BRF.html", "snippet": "Exxon Mobil said it would build a second chemicals factory in Singapore to meet rising demand in Asia.", "lead_paragraph": "Exxon Mobil said it would build a second chemicals factory in Singapore to meet rising demand in Asia. The plant will cost \u201cseveral billion dollars\u201d and will start up in 2011, Eva Ho, a spokeswoman based in Singapore, said. At the heart of the new plant is a cracker, which processes naphtha, an oil product, into ethylene, a raw material for making plastics. {"abstract": "Exxon argued that given the $3.5 billion it has paid in cleanup costs, fines and settlements after the Valdez oil spill, the $2.5 billion in punitive damages is beyond constitutional due process. ", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2007/10/30/business/30bizcourt.html", "snippet": "Exxon argued that given the $3.5 billion it has paid in cleanup costs, fines and settlements after the Valdez oil spill, the $2.5 billion in punitive damages is beyond constitutional due process. ", "lead_paragraph": "WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 \u2014 Nearly 19 years after the tanker Exxon Valdez spilled 11 million gallons of crude oil into Prince William Sound in Alaska, the Supreme Court agreed on Monday to hear Exxon Mobil\u2019s challenge to the $2.5 billion in punitive damages that the company was ordered to pay to thousands of fishermen, landowners and businesses.", "print_section": "C", "print_page": "5", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Justices to Hear Exxon\u2019s Challenge to Punitive Damages", "kicker": null, "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "Justices to Hear Exxon\u2019s Challenge to Punitive Damages", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "subject", "value": "Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "Supreme Court", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "Exxon Mobil Corp", "rank": 3, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Decisions and Verdicts", "rank": 4, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2007-10-30T04:00:00+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "byline": {"original": "By Linda Greenhouse", "person": [{"firstname": "Linda", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Greenhouse", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/54006626-6f87-5b1d-9955-b68fe00a1224", "word_count": 663, "uri": "nyt://article/54006626-6f87-5b1d-9955-b68fe00a1224"}

{"abstract": "The oil industry is known to be very conservative. And Exxon Mobil, the world\u2019s largest publicly traded oil company, may be the most conservative of the bunch. {"abstract": "Record earnings for Exxon, the world\u2019s largest publicly traded oil company, have become routine as the surge of oil prices in recent years has filled its coffers.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2008/08/01/business/01oil.html", "snippet": "Record earnings for Exxon, the world\u2019s largest publicly traded oil company, have become routine as the surge of oil prices in recent years has filled its coffers.", "lead_paragraph": "HOUSTON \u0097 Exxon Mobil reported the best quarterly profit ever for a corporation on Thursday, beating its own record, but investors sold off shares as oil and natural gas prices resumed their recent decline.", "print_section": "C", "print_page": "2", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Exxon\u2019s Second-Quarter Earnings Set a Record", "kicker": null, "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "Exxon\u2019s Second-Quarter Earnings Set a Record", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "subject", "value": "Company Reports", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "Exxon Mobil Corp", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "Royal Dutch Shell Plc", "rank": 3, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2008-08-01T04:00:00+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "byline": {"original": "By Clifford Krauss", "person": [{"firstname": "Clifford", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Krauss", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/0cef7a1e-b995-5729-b7a5-f119846389c1", "word_count": 1051, "uri": "nyt://article/0cef7a1e-b995-5729-b7a5-f119846389c1"}

{"abstract": "Returning from vacation, I arrived home to find at my doorstop the latest issue of Portfolio, the not-quite-new Conde Nast business magazine, whose media critic is one Howell Raines, the former executive editor of The New York Times who left a couple of years before I got here. Anyway, I just read, somewhat dumbfounded, his latest column. It\u2019s about how all of us in business journalism are being sandbagged by those awful people running Exxon Mobil and the other major oil companies, who are busy gouging us while tossing the press their \u201cmalarkey\u201d about supply and demand being behind the rise in oil prices. Raines, apparently, is among the legions who believe it\u2019s all a big plot by Big Oil, which could bring down the price with a snap of its powerful finger.", "web_url": "https://executivesuite.blogs.nytimes.com/2008/08/05/howell-raines-conspiracy-theorist/", "snippet": "", "lead_paragraph": "Returning from vacation, I arrived home to find at my doorstop the latest issue of Portfolio, the not-quite-new Conde Nast business magazine, whose media critic is one Howell Raines, the former executive editor of The New York Times who left a couple of years before I got here. {"abstract": "With BP shares plunging since the oil rig accident, many are speculating about the company\u2019s options, Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in his latest DealBook column.", "web_url": "https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2010/06/08/sorkin-imagining-the-worst-in-bps-future/", "snippet": "With BP shares plunging since the oil rig accident, many are speculating about the company\u2019s options, Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in his latest DealBook column.", "lead_paragraph": "It seems unthinkable, even now, that the disastrous oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico could bring down the mighty BP. {"abstract": "Royal Dutch Shell also reported strong results, following a ConocoPhillips report on Wednesday that its quarterly income had nearly doubled.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2010/10/29/business/29exxon.html", "snippet": "Royal Dutch Shell also reported strong results, following a ConocoPhillips report on Wednesday that its quarterly income had nearly doubled.", "lead_paragraph": "HOUSTON \u0097 Exxon Mobil, the world\u2019s largest publicly traded company, reported on Thursday a larger-than-expected 55 percent rise in its third-quarter profit, helped by higher crude oil prices and increased production of natural gas.", "print_section": "B", "print_page": "3", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Exxon Profit Soars 55% as Oil Prices Rebound", "kicker": null, "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "Exxon Profit Soars 55% As Oil Prices Rebound", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "subject", "value": "Company Reports", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "Exxon Mobil Corp", "rank": 3, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "Royal Dutch Shell Plc", "rank": 4, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2010-10-28T12:31:15+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "byline": {"original": "By Clifford Krauss", "person": [{"firstname": "Clifford", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Krauss", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/61e8e556-7565-507a-9702-15bc4792413d", "word_count": 818, "uri": "nyt://article/61e8e556-7565-507a-9702-15bc4792413d"}

{"abstract": "Separating high-growth exploration activities from sluggish refining and marketing businesses could add billions to market valuations, some analysts say.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/25/business/25views.html", "snippet": "Separating high-growth exploration activities from sluggish refining and marketing businesses could add billions to market valuations, some analysts say.", "lead_paragraph": "Big oil companies could unlock big value for shareholders. But to do so they need to slaughter an industry sacred cow: the integration of the exploration and production business with refining and other activities. This model worked for decades but today accords a conglomerate discount to the likes of Exxon Mobil, Shell and BP. {"abstract": "The Marcellus shale has offered some of the hottest wildcat real estate in recent years, but if Exxon Mobil\u2019s recent $1.7 billion acquisition is any indication, the days of eye-watering prices are over.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2011/06/10/business/10views.html", "snippet": "The Marcellus shale has offered some of the hottest wildcat real estate in recent years, but if Exxon Mobil\u2019s recent $1.7 billion acquisition is any indication, the days of eye-watering prices are over.", "lead_paragraph": "The gas-rich land of the Marcellus shale has offered some of the hottest wildcat real estate in recent years. But if Exxon Mobil\u2019s recent $1.7 billion acquisition is any indication, the days of eye-watering prices are over. The oil titan is paying barely half the price such acres were fetching last year, as the frenzy has shifted to Texas. Cheaper real estate may even make gas assets look appealing again.", "print_section": "B", "print_page": "2", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Prices Fall for Some Gas-Rich Shale Land", "kicker": "Reuters Breakingviews", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "Changing Values For Energy Land", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "persons", "value": "Picard, Irving H", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Natural Gas", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}, {"name": "persons", "value": "Madoff, Bernard L", "rank": 3, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "Exxon Mobil Corporation", "rank": 4, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Suits and Litigation", "rank": 5, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Shale", "rank": 6, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2011-06-10T02:27:11+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "byline": {"original": "By Christopher Swann and Reynolds Holding", "person": [{"firstname": "Christopher", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Swann", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}, {"firstname": "Reynolds", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Holding", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 2}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/6eac539c-4e0b-53a6-ad64-b7253716c4e8", "word_count": 722, "uri": "nyt://article/6eac539c-4e0b-53a6-ad64-b7253716c4e8"}

{"abstract": "The smaller shops have been able to prosper despite the slowdown.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2011/07/29/business/boutique-firms-are-bearing-up.html", "snippet": "The smaller shops have been able to prosper despite the slowdown.", "lead_paragraph": "Wall Street firms that specialize in mergers and acquisitions are hitting a few wobbles after a good run. {"abstract": "The Exxon Mobil Corporation and Kenneth Salazar, the interior secretary, agreed to settle a lawsuit in which Exxon challenged the government\u2019s decision to cancel offshore leases.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2012/01/07/business/energy-environment/exxon-and-salazar-in-settlement-on-offshore-leases.html", "snippet": "The Exxon Mobil Corporation and Kenneth Salazar, the interior secretary, agreed to settle a lawsuit in which Exxon challenged the government\u2019s decision to cancel offshore leases.", "lead_paragraph": "The Exxon Mobil Corporation and Kenneth Salazar, the interior secretary, agreed to settle a lawsuit in which Exxon, the world\u2019s largest publicly traded oil company, challenged the government\u2019s decision to cancel offshore leases that may yield \u201cbillions of barrels of oil,\u201d according to a court filing. The accord \u201cwill allow Exxon Mobil to develop this very large, but technically challenging, resource as quickly as possible using a phased approach,\u201d Patrick McGinn, a spokesman for Exxon, said in an e-mail. Exxon sued on Aug. 12 over a ruling by the department that canceled Gulf of Mexico leases for the so-called Julia unit. The company and the government entered into a settlement agreement on Dec. 30, according to a filing Friday in United States District Court in Lake Charles, Louisiana. Exxon said in its complaint that it sought a suspension for its Julia leases in 2008 because of drilling complexity. It cited federal regulations that allow oil oil producers to suspend production in their fields, partly \u201cto facilitate proper development of a lease.\u201d The Interior Department denied the request in 2009, stating that the company\u201chad not demonstrated a commitment to production\u201d according to court papers. Unsuccessful appeals followed. ", "print_section": "B", "print_page": "2", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Exxon and Salazar in Settlement on Offshore Leases", "kicker": "Business Briefing | Company News", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "Exxon And Salazar In Settlement On Offshore Leases", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "subject", "value": "Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Suits and Litigation", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "Exxon Mobil Corporation", "rank": 3, "major": "N"}, {"name": "persons", "value": "Salazar, Ken", "rank": 4, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Offshore Drilling and Exploration", "rank": 5, "major": "N"}, {"name": "glocations", "value": "Gulf of Mexico", "rank": 6, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2012-01-07T04:11:47+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "subsection_name": "Energy & Environment ", "byline": {"original": "By Bloomberg News", "person": [{"firstname": "Bloomberg", "middlename": null, "lastname": "News", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "Brief", "_id": "nyt://article/eb128722-8572-5796-8ca7-00d7f7e6da73", "word_count": 198, "uri": "nyt://article/eb128722-8572-5796-8ca7-00d7f7e6da73"}

{"abstract": "Many big-name companies are reporting earnings, including Apple, Exxon Mobil, Facebook, General Motors and Chrysler, and the Fed is expected to keep up its stimulus efforts.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2013/10/28/business/economic-reports-for-the-week-of-oct-28.html", "snippet": "Many big-name companies are reporting earnings, including Apple, Exxon Mobil, Facebook, General Motors and Chrysler, and the Fed is expected to keep up its stimulus efforts.", "lead_paragraph": "APPLE EARNINGS Apple has become one of the most valuable companies in the world largely because of the success of iPhones and iPads. But over the last year, the growth of its profit has slowed as fewer people have been upgrading their smartphones each year, and as more competitors have produced low-cost tablets. In response, Apple in September introduced not one, but two new iPhones. When the company announces its third-quarter earnings on Monday, investors and analysts will watch closely to determine whether the new iPhones have given Apple\u2019s profit a much-needed lift. ", "print_section": "B", "print_page": "2", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Economic Reports for the Week of Oct. 28", "kicker": "Looking Ahead", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "Economic Reports for the Week of Oct. 28", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "subject", "value": "Company Reports", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "United States Economy", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "Federal Reserve System", "rank": 3, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "Apple Inc", "rank": 4, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "Facebook Inc", "rank": 5, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2013-10-27T21:32:32+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "byline": {"original": "", "person": [], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "List", "_id": "nyt://article/6db33c77-a812-5b73-b410-3c566a487626", "word_count": 346, "uri": "nyt://article/6db33c77-a812-5b73-b410-3c566a487626"}

{"abstract": "Firms that track benefit plans are finding their terms are improving for many employees, in areas such as company matching, vesting and fees.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2014/03/13/business/retirementspecial/the-best-401-k-s-set-a-higher-bar-for-others.html", "snippet": "Firms that track benefit plans are finding their terms are improving for many employees, in areas such as company matching, vesting and fees.", "lead_paragraph": "EVERY December for five years, BrightScope, a financial research firm based in San Diego, has published a list of the top 30 401(k) plans. These standouts provide, among other qualities, generous company contributions, quick access to that corporate money, low fees and a wide array of investment options. {"abstract": "The pipeline group Kinder Morgan plans to reorganize as a single corporation. | The drop in Treasury yields has confounded experts. | An investor group is considering legal action after being burned by losses on Portuguese bank bonds. | A Stanford finance professor is rapidly gaining a broader audience.", "web_url": "https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2014/08/11/morning-agenda-kinder-morgan-to-consolidate/", "snippet": "The pipeline group Kinder Morgan plans to reorganize as a single corporation. | The drop in Treasury yields has confounded experts. | An investor group is considering legal action after being burned by losses on Portuguese bank bonds. | A Stanford...", "lead_paragraph": "KINDER MORGAN TO REORGANIZE | The pipeline group Kinder Morgan, the biggest of the master limited partnerships, announced on Sunday that it would acquire its three associated companies and reorganize as one corporation based in Houston, DealBook\u2019s David Gelles writes. The new Kinder Morgan will have an estimated enterprise value of about $140 billion \u2012 $100 billion of market value and $40 billion of debt \u2012 making it the third-biggest energy company in the United States, after Exxon Mobil and Chevron.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Morning Agenda: Kinder Morgan to Consolidate", "kicker": "DealBook", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [], "pub_date": "2014-08-11T12:53:35+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "byline": {"original": "By Sydney Ember", "person": [{"firstname": "Sydney", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Ember", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/842ea6ba-b42f-5636-bc14-f23cc666bcd2", "word_count": 1896, "uri": "nyt://article/842ea6ba-b42f-5636-bc14-f23cc666bcd2"}

{"abstract": "After decades of resistance, the oil behemoth is taking carefully considered steps to support gay, lesbian, bisexual and transgender employees.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2015/07/02/business/exxon-lumbers-along-to-catch-up-with-gay-rights.html", "snippet": "After decades of resistance, the oil behemoth is taking carefully considered steps to support gay, lesbian, bisexual and transgender employees.", "lead_paragraph": "A day after the United States Supreme Court affirmed same-sex marriage as a right, more than 125 Exxon Mobil employees marched in the Houston L.G.B.T.
